Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Roll-to-Roll Manufacturing of Films and Laminates Based on Cellulose Nanomaterials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
While the potential applications of nanocomposites have stimulated much research, many practical barriers exist in production scale-up, and their environmental issues have raised significant concerns. These factors are driving a growing demand for nanomaterials that are produced from renewable sources that are also highly processable. Cellulose nanomaterials represent one promising class of materials. However, the scalable manufacture of these materials has yet to be established, due to scientific and engineering challenges that are unique to their dispersions. At present, cellulose nanomaterials based nanocomposite films are prepared by casting methods that can only produce small-area samples with limited quality control, or by press/filtration methods that produce sheets with a high density of structural defects. This Scalable NanoManufacturing (SNM) award will study continuous casting methods for the roll-to-roll fabrication of these films and laminates. The research will result in a capability of producing sufficiently large areas for practical vacuum- and thermo-forming applications. Breakthrough technologies and approaches to scaling up production of these films and laminates, large area continuous manufacturing, and new algorithms in process control can revolutionize many applications in packaging and structural materials. The interest expressed by industrial partners in this technology attest to the potential impact of the project in industrial innovation. Moreover developing scalable production of cellulose nanomaterial films and laminates will allow replacement of fossil fuel-derived materials, thus lowering environmental footprint and lead to a more sustainable economy.

The scalable production of cellulose nanomaterial enhanced laminate materials will be supported by sustainable and eco-friendly approaches for surface modification and particle dispersion, by fundamental advances in controlling the rheology of complex fluids for uniform film deposition, and by a cross-disciplinary approach toward process monitoring and control during continuous roll-to-toll nanomanufacturing. Multi-scale modeling of cellulose nanomaterial-polymer interfaces and process optimization will deepen our understanding of the interplay between structure and materials properties at different length scales. The simulation tools and computational models developed in the course of this project will be widely applicable to the development of other types of nanocomposites as well as continuous processes for film manufacturing. Specifically, the following barriers will be addressed: scalable production of cellulose nanomaterial-derived films and laminates, process monitoring and control, and understanding the effect of interfaces and microstructures on film processing and mechanical properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this project, in terms of Intellectual Merit, all technical objectives were met for the Roll-to-Roll (R2R) processing of Cellulose (CN) Films and Laminates.  Objective 1 was to develop “green” chemical modification methods of Cellulose Nanocrystals (CNCs) and Cellulose Nanofibrils (CNFs) to enable incorporation into hydrophobic plastics.  Two methods were developed, one utilizing water as a green solvent and the other using mechano-chemical solventless methods as shown in figure 1.  High degrees of modification were attained.  Objective 2 was to develop R2R methods and formulations to prepare coatings and films of CN.  R2R of both CNC and CNF was successful and produced adherent and transparent coatings as shown in figure 2.  Rheological parameters were related to formulations that enabled R2R. Objective 3 was to develop methods and algorithms aimed at the in-line process monitoring of R2R of CN.  A real time imaging system and a quality control algorithm were developed utilizing high speed optical imaging to detect and type defects.  Figure 3 shows a “poor” coating with defects detected and categorized.  An off-line method for determining anisotropy in CN films was also developed that allows faster and easier measurement with common, low-cost instrumentation.  Objective 4 was to utilize computational modelling to investigate the role of CN structure and interfaces on properties. Models were developed for the helical arrangement of CNCs found when dried as well as the effects of interfacial strength, length, dispersity, and orientation of the CNCs on the mechanical properties. The general trends of these results were subsequently experimentally observed.  Figure 4 shows models of two distributions of particles. Objective 5 was to understand how R2R processing affects CN microstructure and resultant properties.  Most effort was geared at CNC as it was found that a high degree of alignment could be achieved with the R2R process.  This alignment was found to result in an extremely high barrier performance to oxygen and carbon dioxide and lowered water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) as shown in Figure 5.  Thus, the R2R method was developed for a variety of substrates aimed at sustainable food packaging. Further, aligned CNC composites were found to have some of the highest thermal conductivities in non-electrically polymeric materials ever found. Lastly, the technical results of Objectives 1-5 led to non-proposed research directions that resulted in discovering that CNC-based nanocomposite wood coatings can attain higher scratch and chip resistance, discovery of high CN content water-borne polyurethane coatings with a high hardness suitable for metal and other surfaces, fluorine-free superhydrophobic coatings made of natural sustainable materials that can be regenerated by sanding or peeling with tape, and CN-nanocomposite encapsulation materials that are more resilient to breakage and can be used for phase change material (PCM) applications, such as for de-icing of roads.

 

In terms of Broader Impacts, in addition to multiple firsts (e.g. first R2R aligned CNC film, etc), the research performed has led to multiple innovations that resulted in multiple patent applications on the R2R process and advanced polyurethane and superhydrophobic coatings. Further the publications sponsored by this research have already garnered hundreds of citations, indicating the impact on this and other fields. The computational tools developed were placed on Purdue’s Nanohub for use by other research groups. Educationally, overall, eight Ph.D. students and an M.S. student were directly funded and able to graduate with a STEM degree from this research and multiple undergraduate students were involved with the research.  For outreach, multiple ½-day outreach demonstrations were given at Purdue’s Nanodays, as well as outreach at other venues to promote STEM disciplines.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: During the course of this project, in terms of Intellectual Merit, all technical objectives were met for the Roll-to-Roll (R2R) processing of Cellulose (CN) Films and Laminates. Objective 1 was to develop "green" chemical modification methods of Cellulose Nanocrystals (CNCs) and Cellulose Nanofibrils (CNFs) to enable incorporation into hydrophobic plastics. Two methods were developed, one utilizing water as a green solvent and the other using mechano-chemical solventless methods as shown in figure 1. High degrees of modification were attained. Objective 2 was to develop R2R methods and formulations to prepare coatings and films of CN. R2R of both CNC and CNF was successful and produced adherent and transparent coatings as shown in figure 2. Rheological parameters were related to formulations that enabled R2R. Objective 3 was to develop methods and algorithms aimed at the in-line process monitoring of R2R of CN. A real time imaging system and a quality control algorithm were developed utilizing high speed optical imaging to detect and type defects. Figure 3 shows a "poor" coating with defects detected and categorized. An off-line method for determining anisotropy in CN films was also developed that allows faster and easier measurement with common, low-cost instrumentation. Objective 4 was to utilize computational modelling to investigate the role of CN structure and interfaces on properties. Models were developed for the helical arrangement of CNCs found when dried as well as the effects of interfacial strength, length, dispersity, and orientation of the CNCs on the mechanical properties. The general trends of these results were subsequently experimentally observed. Figure 4 shows models of two distributions of particles. Objective 5 was to understand how R2R processing affects CN microstructure and resultant properties. Most effort was geared at CNC as it was found that a high degree of alignment could be achieved with the R2R process. This alignment was found to result in an extremely high barrier performance to oxygen and carbon dioxide and lowered water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) as shown in Figure 5. Thus, the R2R method was developed for a variety of substrates aimed at sustainable food packaging. Further, aligned CNC composites were found to have some of the highest thermal conductivities in non-electrically polymeric materials ever found. Lastly, the technical results of Objectives 1-5 led to non-proposed research directions that resulted in discovering that CNC-based nanocomposite wood coatings can attain higher scratch and chip resistance, discovery of high CN content water-borne polyurethane coatings with a high hardness suitable for metal and other surfaces, fluorine-free superhydrophobic coatings made of natural sustainable materials that can be regenerated by sanding or peeling with tape, and CN-nanocomposite encapsulation materials that are more resilient to breakage and can be used for phase change material (PCM) applications, such as for de-icing of roads. In terms of Broader Impacts, in addition to multiple firsts (e.g. first R2R aligned CNC film, etc), the research performed has led to multiple innovations that resulted in multiple patent applications on the R2R process and advanced polyurethane and superhydrophobic coatings. Further the publications sponsored by this research have already garnered hundreds of citations, indicating the impact on this and other fields. The computational tools developed were placed on Purdue’s Nanohub for use by other research groups. Educationally, overall, eight Ph.D. students and an M.S. student were directly funded and able to graduate with a STEM degree from this research and multiple undergraduate students were involved with the research. For outreach, multiple ½-day outreach demonstrations were given at Purdue’s Nanodays, as well as outreach at other venues to promote STEM disciplines.
